body:
I've been using vim for years to write prose, books, letters, tex, and to write code, and now I'm considering neovim because of this.

I've been growing increasingly frustrated by the lack of a nice way to navigate through long lines. And yes, I've remapped j and k to gj and gk, but yet all the other nice ways to scroll and navigate through text remain absolutely unusable (c-e, c-y, mouse wheel scroll, c-d, c-u...). Through the years I've found a very big number of topics on this subject, and many users that have requested this function. Many of them tried hard to get into it but end up getting really frustrated by its scrolling behavior and then give up.

**Can we please add an option that makes vim consider equal the soft wrapped (visual) lines and the hard wrapped lines? This will make my job infinitely more easy and enjoyable too.**

It's a bit weird to link to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7172 and then open a new issue here, but I'll close that one since this has more references.

Nothing is going to materialize for this, however, unless someone sends a pull request with test coverage. [This thread](http://vim.1045645.n5.nabble.com/Scrolling-screen-lines-I-knew-it-s-impossible-td3358342.html) (or Vim's `todo.txt`) is a good place to start regarding design.

Vim issue: https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/3188

Thanks for taking this into consideration. I hope that someone notices this and suddenly feels the desire to write some useful code. 
I think that line wrapping is one of the biggest problems that keeps away the beginners from the neovim world.
Is there something we can do to reach more developers or more users that may want the same feature?

@GianniGi:
> Is there something we can do to reach more developers or more users that may want the same feature?

Other than opening an issue on a tracker that > 1K github users get notifications for and upvoting your own posts? I don't think so.
Maybe this is just not as important/urgent to the majority as it is to you or maybe it is just much harder to do than you think and people refrain from tackling it.

I guess the fasted way to get this would be to be pro-active and attempt a pull-request yourself.
If this is out of the question, as far as I am concerned, you have done all you can do for now to make your point.

---
***edit:***

@GianniGi: It seems you misinterpreted my comment about the upvotes as an offense. I'm sorry to see that. I honestly meant to answer your question by pointing out that more than 1000 people saw your post but most 'support' it got came from you. So probably there is nothing more you can do. I did not intend to say you are wrong with this issue or clicking the icons. It's just that from my point of view, all you suggested has been around before. So other than compiling all the information and raising some attention to it, the only thing you could do would be providing a solution yourself.

By posting in this issue every few days without any new information (just to 'bump' the issue) I think it is more likely that repository watchers unsubscribe from this particular issue than someone coming up with a simple solution he/she didn't come up 4 days before. :wink:

So the intention of this post was not to offend you but to show that people read your messages, take them serious and not getting your feature in a short amount of time is not a sign for nobody caring.

Also, less than 400 people have so far contributed code to Neovim but you reached more than a thousand with this issue. I justed wanted you to consider that lack of reach might not be the thing that is blocking this feature.

OMG sorry for clicking some decorative icons, what a big big mistake :-D

I've added more upvotes, seems good.

Ok, it's the wrong context. I removed.

From what I understood you just stopped using soft line wrap and are using hard ones. This isn't the same as seen [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/8715#issuecomment-531425987). What we are willing to have is a way to scroll the screen line by line with soft wraps instead of turning them into hard line breaks.

I've been mulling over the idea of row-wise scrolling from a similar use-case where it's necessary for me to know the bounds (column-wise start + end) of displayed physical lines. Perhaps the ideas could be applied for this as well.

From https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/11014 and this thread's discussions I understood that one of the reasons why row-wise scrolling is hard is due to Neovim's internal data structures not being primed for this use-case (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/11014#issuecomment-536761143). It looks like the implementation of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/11014 @ 7d333c6d297bf03b2cde77d4c54294bd587572d1 requires recomputing physical lines up to the cursor position and that would be slow for long lines.

What I've been thinking about revolves around computing displayed physical lines' bounds based on the amount of skipped **line buffer characters** from the top line (which is not `w_skipcol` since `w_skipcol` also counts virtual characters such as `showbreak`). Starting from that offset we'd continuously slice line fragments until the whole available text area for the current screen is filled, therefore knowing the displayed physical lines' bounds. Having this data could allow for a crude manner of userland row-wise scrolling, e.g. to scroll down (assumes `set scrolloff=0`):

```
If on the bottom physical line:
  Input "gj"
Otherwise:
  Save cursor position
  Go to the bottom physical line
  Input "gj", therefore making the window scroll
  Restore the cursor position
    Note: + 1 line if it cursor was at the top physical line, since it was scrolled off the screen
```

That being said, since the bottom physical line's bounds would be known, it should be possible to infer the next one's bounds without scrolling the screen.

I'm unsure if I'm missing or misunderstanding something which would make this idea unreasonable.

The issue with this is that current neo-/vim is not capable of showing more than one line on screen if the beginning of the first line is not shown (at least that's my recollection, it's been a while since I've played with this). If you were to input "gj" on the last row of a line that filled the whole screen, the entire line is scrolled off screen (and likewise with scrolling up). I'm not sure how you'd get a usable row-wise scrolling just from userspace modifications, but it'd be nice to be proven wrong! Or maybe for your use case the jumpiness doesn't matter?

According to the last comment I made on the pull request, this is apparently not too far from being mergeable as an experimental feature. I haven't had much time for open source work in a while, but maybe I can brush that code off sometime soon.

If you were to input "gj" on the last row of a line that filled the whole screen, the entire line is scrolled off screen (and likewise with scrolling up).

I was considering "row-wise scrolling" merely as the capability of shifting the text in terms of physical lines, without regards for how it was presented. I wasn't taking into consideration much of what you said there when it comes to look and feel, so apologies.

> Or maybe for your use case the jumpiness doesn't matter?

Yes, it wouldn't matter for me. What I described there is more like "text scrolling in terms of physical lines" rather than the "row-wise scrolling" being envisioned for that feature as I perceive it now.

> According to the last comment I made on the pull request, this is apparently not too far from being mergeable as an experimental feature. I haven't had much time for open source work in a while, but maybe I can brush that code off sometime soon.

I saw one of your mentions about how bothersome it is to grapple with some of the options. It definitely feels that way even from an outsider's perspective, but I hope it's not bad enough to discourage you from pursuing the idea. Best of luck with your PR. :-)

FTR, the original vim project [claims to have added an option `smoothscroll`](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/3188#issuecomment-1336132779) to solve that issue. So for compatibility purposes I think would be useful to have the option implementing that named similarly.
The `smoothscroll` option for vim works as intended, so are there any updates on this feature in Neovim?
Somebody needs to port the patches. Maybe you?

If you want to port the Vim `smoothscroll` patches over, you may want to just gather the full list of commits first as a lower effort initial work just to gauge the scope, since there are quite a few over the months as the initial feature was quite buggy and could result in cursor flying off the window. I [had 5](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues?q=author%3Aychin+smoothscroll) myself, and there are quite a few other ones. It could be useful to look at them as a whole if you don't want to retrace all the bug -> fix bugs commits and thought process.
To have it mentioned, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23320 is not handling `scrolloff` and it still jumps when scrolling with j/k in some circumstances. Should I open a separate issue?
